overall_score_comment: Like Houdini himself, the lyrical depth has completely vanished.
the_roast:
Dua Lipa really said 'what if I named a song after one of history's greatest escape artists and then just... repeated the same four lines until everyone desperately wanted to escape?' The entire song is basically 'I come and I go' sung seventeen different ways, like she's stuck in a revolving door and decided to make it her whole personality. 'Catch me or I go Houdini' — girl, Houdini was famous for PLANNED escapes from handcuffs and water tanks, not just being flaky at parties. This is less magic trick, more ghosting someone on a dating app.

The bridge attempts depth with 'Time is passin' like a solar eclipse' which sounds profound until you realize solar eclipses last like two minutes, so yeah, accurate metaphor for this song's substance. Then we get 'do you practice everything that you preach?' which is rich coming from someone whose entire lyrical sermon is 'maybe convince me to stay... but also I'm leaving... but maybe I'm not... actually I'm definitely leaving... unless?' Pick a lane, Dua! This is the musical equivalent of those people who announce they're leaving the party five times but are still there two hours later.

The real crime is 'Prove you got the right to please me' repeated ad nauseam like it's some kind of empowerment anthem, when really it just sounds like she's conducting boyfriend auditions with the charisma of a DMV clerk. And 'Maybe you could cause a girl to change her ways' — so the whole 'I come and I go' thing is just a personality trait she's WAITING for someone to fix? That's not mysterious, that's just commitment issues with a disco beat.

lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Locked in a water tank with only this song playing on loop.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Everything you say is soundin' so sweet / But do you practice everything that you preach?
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Rhyming sweet with preach like we wouldn't notice thatreach
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forced to attend a rhyming dictionary intervention led by Eminem.

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a profound meditation on quantum superposition — Dua exists in multiple emotional states simultaneously, both present and absent, committed and distant, until observed by a partner who can 'make her believe.' Either that, or she just really liked the word 'Houdini' and built an entire song around not having to commit to anything, including a second verse.
final_verdict: This song disappears more than Houdini ever did, except instead of leaving audiences amazed, it leaves them wondering why they just heard the same four lines for three minutes straight. The real magic trick would've been making these lyrics more substantial than a fortune cookie.
title: Houdini
